title: Dexter Howard
text:
I am a PhD candidate in the Carey Lab at Virginia Tech, specializing in water quality research. My research focuses on organic carbon dynamics in reservoirs and how these change over both spatial and temporal scales using field sampling, analytical techniques, and modeling.
I am passionate about education and have gained experience through laboratory instruction and development of educational modules.

title: Teaching
text:
I am passionate about education and preparing the next generation to tackle pressing environmental issues. I have worked on two separate educational modules while in graduate school in addition to teaching multiple lab sessions.




Virginia Tech, Biological Sciences

During the Fall semesters in 2021 - 2025, I led a lab of approximately 16 students and assisting with another of similar size. My role involved guiding students on field trips and lab activities, teaching the fundamentals of freshwater ecology sampling and monitoring. I helped students develop and execute semester-long group research projects, where they developed their own research questions, collected and analyzed data, and presented their results. As the lab session instructor, I was responsible for all grading, and I also assisted with exam grading for the lecture component of the class.







We developed a set of case studies modules to be used in undergraduate or graduate classes that discuss ethical considerations of developing and disseminating ecological forecasts. These modules were developed with collaborators from the Ecological Forecasting Initiative.
Article on modules: Lewis et al. 2024. Ethics in forecasting: a case-based learning set. Teaching Issues and Experiments in Ecology. Vol. 19: Practice #13.
Teaching resources additionally hosted at QUBES Educational Resources. doi:10.25334/5D99-Y019



Co-developed a self-paced course for Virginia Tech students and employees to teach about Native American communities, their citizens, current challenges, and support strategies. This module was developed with collaborators from the Ati: Wa:oki Indigenous Community Center and Global Change Center at Virginia Tech.

title: Teaching
text:
My approach emphasizes: - Hands-on learning
- Authentic research experiences
- Clear, reproducible workflows
- Supporting students as they develop scientific questions and analytical skills

text:

title: Research
text: I have wide-ranging experiences in aquatic ecology. I have worked on projects spanning carbon and nutrient cycling to plankton community composition using a variety of field, laboratory, and modeling techniques.

title: Research
text: I have wide-ranging experiences in aquatic ecology. I have worked on projects spanning carbon and nutrient cycling to plankton community composition using a variety of field, laboratory, and modeling techniques.

title: Research
text:
Reservoir Organic Carbon Dynamics
Since 2018, I have worked on multiple projects examining the drivers and variability of organic carbon (OC) in drinking water reservoirs.

PhD Projects


Understanding stream OC exports using hydro-ecological models
Spatial patterns of OC composition and concentration across a reservoir watershed
Forecastability of OC concentrations using high-frequency sensors and meteorological forecasts
Effects of variable ice cover on lake metabolism (GPP and ER) in a southern Appalachian reservoir




Previous Work

Undergraduate senior thesis on OC variability using high-frequency sensors and time-series modeling

title: Research
text:
Broader Interests

Limnology

Aquatic biogeochemistry

Drinking water quality

Ecological forecasting

Environmental data science
